messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 52 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Spectral Sparsification via Bounded-Independence Sampling

Paper Abstract: Abstract We give a deterministic, nearly logarithmic-space algorithm for mild spectral sparsification of undirected graphs. Given a weighted, undirected graph G𝐺G on n𝑛n vertices described by a binary string of length N𝑁N, an integer k≤log⁡n𝑘𝑛k\leq\log n, and an error parameter ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, our algorithm runs in space O~​(k​log⁡(N⋅wmax/wmin))~𝑂𝑘⋅𝑁subscript𝑤maxsubscript𝑤min\widetilde{O}(k\log(N\cdot w_{\mathrm{max}}/w_{\mathrm{min}})) where wmaxsubscript𝑤maxw_{\mathrm{max}} and wminsubscript𝑤minw_{\mathrm{min}} are the maximum and minimum edge weights in G𝐺G, and produces a weighted graph H𝐻H with O~​(n1+2/k/ε2)~𝑂superscript𝑛12𝑘superscript𝜀2\widetilde{O}(n^{1+2/k}/\varepsilon^{2}) edges that spectrally approximates G𝐺G, in the sense of Spielmen and Teng [ST04], up to an error of ε𝜀\varepsilon. Our algorithm is based on a new bounded-independence analysis of Spielman and Srivastava’s effective resistance based edge sampling algorithm [SS11] and uses results from recent work on space-bounded Laplacian solvers [MRSV17]. In particular, we demonstrate an inherent tradeoff (via upper and lower bounds) between the amount of (bounded) independence used in the edge sampling algorithm, denoted by k𝑘k above, and the resulting sparsity that can be achieved.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 52 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 52"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "A fast and simple randomized parallel algorithm for the maximal independent set problem",
        "High-precision estimation of random walks in small space",
        "k𝑘k-wise independent random graphs",
        "Spectral sparsification and regret minimization beyond matrix multiplicative updates",
        "Note on the girth of Ramanujan graphs",
        "Approximating s​-​t𝑠-𝑡s\\mbox{-}t minimum cuts in O~​(n2)~𝑂superscript𝑛2\\widetilde{O}(n^{2}) time",
        "Modern graph theory, volume 184",
        "Twice-ramanujan sparsifiers",
        "Graph sparsification, spectral sketches, and faster resistance computation, via short cycle decompositions",
        "The masked sample covariance estimator: An analysis using matrix concentration inequalities",
        "There are planar graphs almost as good as the complete graph",
        "Solving directed Laplacian systems in nearly-linear time through sparse LU factorizations",
        "Electrical flows, Laplacian systems, and faster approximation of maximum flow in undirected graphs",
        "Solving SDD linear systems in nearly m​log1/2⁡n𝑚superscript12𝑛m\\log^{1/2}n time",
        "Faster algorithms for computing the stationary distribution, simulating random walks, and more",
        "Almost-linear-time algorithms for Markov chains and new spectral primitives for directed graphs",
        "Negative-weight shortest paths and unit capacity minimum cost flow in O~​(m10/7​log⁡W)~𝑂superscript𝑚107𝑊\\widetilde{O}(m^{10/7}\\log{W}) time",
        "Probabilistic logarithmic-space algorithms for Laplacian solvers",
        "Dynamic cage survey",
        "Reguläre graphen gegebener taillenweite mit minimaler knotenzahl",
        "The average impedance of an electrical network",
        "On a set of almost deterministic k𝑘k-independent random variables",
        "An almost-linear-time algorithm for approximate max flow in undirected graphs, and its multicommodity generalizations",
        "Sparsified Cholesky and multigrid solvers for connection Laplacians",
        "Faster generation of random spanning trees",
        "A nearly-m​log⁡n𝑚𝑛m\\log n time solver for SDD linear systems",
        "Approaching optimality for solving SDD linear systems",
        "Combinatorial preconditioners and multilevel solvers for problems in computer vision and image processing",
        "A simple, combinatorial algorithm for solving SDD systems in nearly-linear time",
        "Approximate Gaussian elimination for Laplacians-fast, sparse, and simple",
        "Ramanujan graphs",
        "A new approach to computing maximum flows using electrical flows",
        "Efficient accelerated coordinate descent methods and faster algorithms for solving linear systems",
        "Constructing linear-sized spectral sparsification in almost-linear time",
        "An SDP-based algorithm for linear-sized spectral sparsification",
        "Faster energy maximization for faster maximum flow",
        "A simple parallel algorithm for the maximal independent set problem",
        "A new series of dense graphs of high girth",
        "Derandomization beyond connectivity: Undirected Laplacian systems in nearly logarithmic space",
        "Deterministic approximation of random walks in small space",
        "Fast generation of random spanning trees and the effective resistance metric",
        "Approximating the exponential, the Lanczos method and an O~​(m)~𝑂𝑚\\widetilde{O}(m)-time spectral algorithm for balanced separator",
        "An efficient parallel solver for SDD linear systems",
        "Cognitive networked sensing and big data",
        "Undirected connectivity in log-space",
        "Derandomized squaring of graphs",
        "Sampling from large matrices: An approach through geometric functional analysis",
        "An almost-linear time algorithm for uniform random spanning tree generation",
        "Yale Applied Mathematics 561/Computer Science 662, Lecture Notes: Spectral Graph Theory, November 2015",
        "Graph sparsification by effective resistances",
        "Nearly-linear time algorithms for graph partitioning, graph sparsification, and solving linear systems",
        "A matrix hyperbolic cosine algorithm and applications"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 52 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Spectral Sparsification via Bounded-Independence Sampling, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
